You understate your case, Paul. The inflation hawks are wrong at a more fundamental level. Their incorrect assumption is that monetary inflation is a bad thing. Within reason, it is merely neutral, as a decline in the value of green slips of paper or 0's and 1's in the bank affects all prices, including wages. While there are some second order effects, and particular groups of people may have speculative bets about the future inflation rate, the effects of monetary inflation are minimal.

Monetary inflation can be contrasted with real inflation that occurs when the cost of particular goods or services rise due to negative supply shocks. This case, unlike monetary inflation, represents a real loss of wealth and is a negative. This, however, has nothing to do with money printing, but rather real-world events.

So not only are the inflationistas wrong in their prediction that inflation will happen, they are wrong in assuming that it would be a substantial negative even if it did. Well, not completely wrong, as it would be bad for bankers (who have made a lot of bets that inflation will be low), and a disproportionate number of bankers are to be found among the inflationista crowd... Go figure that.

There is only one explanation, and I think you would agree. It is,  increased interest rates will definitely result in a greater accumulation of wealth for the ultra rich, and continued pressure on the "people", thereby maintaining and increasing their command and control.

I'm very happy that "General Dempsey said that American allies in the region must play a role as well." The last thing the US or any EU country wants to do is get involved in another Mideast War. So far, the EU countries' response has been typical: ISIS is horrible, it must be defeated and we're sending humanitarian aid. Yet, very single EU country has been silent about participating in the fighting; and Presdient Obama has tipped the EU countries off that the US has absolutely no intention of unilaterally sacrificing our youth and spending a fortune in another MIdeast OR European conflict.

Poland's recent response to the Ukraine crisis indicates that the EU has not totally adjusted to this long overdue new normal. In regard to the threat of Russian invasion, Poland made snide remarks about how the US just wasn't the reliable ally it used to be (meaning we would not do all their fighting for them); and Poland consequntly increased its budjet to defend itself. Yet, Poland much touted defense budget increase was a whopping 2%.

ISIS DOES need to be eliminated, but after the budget busting failure of the first Iraq War, the US cannot be expected to do more than merely contain ISIS, if we have to do this alone. And when we talk about involvement of EU countries, we mean SUBSTANTIAL involvement, not a token force of a couple hundred soldiers.

America wisely has chosen to no longer be the world's police.

The Scottish should definitely dump the Pound & create their own sovereign currency.

The Scottish Franc could start at par with the British Pound without any requirement to convert any accounts.

Then the new Scottish government would start paying it's employees in Francs & only accept Francs for payment of taxes. This would support the value of the new currency by creating instant & persuasive demand for the new currency. (You go to jail if you don't pay your taxes).

Then the Scottish government could lower tax rates to reduce unemployment.

The problem with anecdotal accounts of inflation is that they are almost always wrong. Gas prices soared - nearly tripled - from 2001 through 2008 when there was no quantitative easing. Since 2011 they have traded in a relatively narrow range and are slightly down.

I used to have a business partner who would loudly grouse about rampant inflation every time a fruit or vegetable he purchased at the local, upscale supermarket went up. When the prices lowered six or eight months later because the product was in season or the drought/flood whatever had abated, he would forget. Furthermore, the inflation addled ignore many long term trends. I bought my first computer for $5,000 in 1980. It ran at 1 Mhz, had 32K of memory, a floppy disk and no hard drive. My most recent purchase was for $700 in 2014 dollars; it is hard to quantify how much more capable. In the '60s I would pay $2.78 a minute to call relatives on the West Coast and it would hard to describe how much real air fare prices have dropped.

Inflation hawks are not practicing science but a slightly demented religion.
Why not just let ISIS fight with Assad on their West, and Iran on their East.  They'll have their hands full!  No need for us to intervene.

What an overly-simplistic solution to an extremely complex problem. Haven't we learned anything from the experience of going into Iraq behind a president who didn't know the difference between a Sunni and a Shiite?

No, it's a mistake.  War is bad for economy.  It keeps us busy producing weapons and ammunition that is being used up somewhere halfway across the world; but all this extra work doesn't improve our lives.

Why are you surprised? Didn't we arm Sadaam Hussein in the late 80s so he could fight the Iranians? And now we're supposed to ask the Iranians to contain the Sunnis? Last time I looked I don't think it was that simple.
Treasonous behavior has become so commonplace in the West that we hardly recognize it when it happens.

If the US military and intelligence doesn't know exactly who ISIS is and who's funding them by now we might as well crawl into our bunkers.  Problem is we know exactly who is funding them.  And we can't do much about it.

ISIS is in a very weak position.  They are trying to set themselves up in unfriendly territory, between Shiite Iran, and a Shiite-led Assad's Syria.  ISIS will be fighting on two fronts; in addition, they will keep Iran busy.   This is going to play out well for the West - there's no need to intervene.
It wasn'tg "we", it was Bush, Cheney and the other oil barons who wanted that oil for themselves.
Actually depleted uranium! All the better to puncture tank armor.

ISIS is not a serious threat once they engage in taking territories. It is not hard to kill cockroaches once you know where they nest. The real victims are the Syrian and the Iraqi people who encounter these godless people.

If the Arab States are serious about defeating ISIS they must put on their big boy pants and jump in.  I don't think for one minute the Arab States are serious about defeating ISIS.  Once ISIS is openly operating in their country and a few Islamic religious leaders have their heads cut off will the Arab States get moving. Until then they will be satisfied with the US taking the lead.

Can somebody explain why ISIS is so much worse than any of the other de facto "Islamic states" that exist in the Arabian Peninsula, i.e. Saudi Arabia, Qatar, Bahrain, Oman, etc.? I mean, are any of these places safe havens for Jews, Buddhists, Christians, or nonreligious people (besides the investment banking class) who just want to be left alone? Would Yazidis have a fighting chance in the land of Wahhabism?

From what I understand, ISIS-supporting Saudi Arabia is still a country where women convicted of adultery can be buried up to their necks in sand and stoned to death according to the rule of law. Is that not just as bad as beheading a hostage? The USA is, beyond any question, the abused spouse in that bilateral relationship. The day Washington declares its opposition to the continued influence of Wahhabism in Riyadh--then I'll know we're getting to the heart of the matter.
Today, Reagan would be cast out of the GOP as a liberal.
And that diminished $102,000 still puts a household in the top 20%. Think of what the great-unwashed bottom 80% of American households have to contend with.

I completely agree.  My employment career began in the late 70s and my pay has been pretty much stagnant since then.  In 20 years at a major public university, I received exactly one cost of living raise, in the early 2000s.  Meanwhile the cost to attend the liberal arts college I attended in the 70s has risen by well over a factor of ten.

For almost my entire career ,I have had to deal with the eroding value of my work. The one thing that George H W Bush nailed perfectly was his description of the supply side theory as "voodoo economics". The American people have seen the biggest transfer of wealth in our nation's history under this philosophy, to the point that the money amassed at the top has totally corrupted the political system. Even Ronald Reagan acknowledged the need for revenue to meet expenditures. But the myth still persists, and a whole generation of conservatives have drunk the Kool Aid and still believe that it will work.
A recent calculation using the Bureau of Labor Statistics inflation calculator shows that a teacher in New York City, whose top annual salary in 1971 was $21,000, would have to be making 123,585 today just to maintain the same buying power. The maximum currently as the new contract kicks in slowly, is $102,000, a 20% reduction in purchasing power. This while real estate has become speculative instead of a home to live in, and a college education has soared beyond the means of most working Americans.
After thirty years of this economic nonsense, how these "inflation hawks" have the chutzpah to say anything about the US economy is beyond me.
And their hypocrisy remains overwhelming. To see Rep. Paul Ryan take the "ice bucket challenge" to raise money for ALS after he voted (as part of the sequestration vote) to cut funding for ALS sums it all up, they simply don't care.

Private and public pensions should be unnecessary.  Taxation of excess wealth could allow us to rebuild our infrastructure and educate our citizenry.  We are becoming two separate societies, and in the end that cannot be sustained.

The reason for these constant warnings about inflation has no rational answer in the science of economics which is a fact based science that keeps records. The real reason is the gullibility of much of the public and the calculated efforts of a class of wealthy elites to deceive them for their own interests.

In the 1930's a mainstay of the county fair midway was the fortune teller’s tent and the snake oil hawker. Step right up and for just one buck, four quarters, you can buy a pint of Doc Ryan’s Magic Elixir for all that ails you. You say you have a tooth ache, lumbago, constipation, gas, arthritis, cancer, heart problems. unemployed? If it troubles, just swallow Doc Ryan’Magic Elixir will do the trick. It contains tax cuts for the wealthy, deregulation of business and privatization of government as the active ingredients. Guaranteed to contain no government job creation or investment in infrastructure or education and it is 100% democracy free.

The fortune teller will read your palm and predict inflation for a dollar and every palm get the same prediction. Many Americans believe in predictions based on nothing in particular but the persuasiveness of the fortune teller, (see CNBC) or some quick ideological fix with ineffective or dangerous ingredients. P.T. Barnum had it right: “There is a sucker born every minute.” There is one area where the right wing has everyone else beat. They are master liars and propagandists and they lye recklessly and with impunity.

Social Security surplus funds are in the trillions of dollars. And as DGA in NYare points out, they are invested in Federal bonds, which pay virtually nothing.

At the same time, huge amounts of tax funds are lent as mortgages at about 5% thru banks. Today's banks really do no lending, they merely are conduits for Federal taxpayer funds. Over 90% of home loans are immediately sold to Federal agencies by the bank that nominally lends the money.

This enriches the Federal government, which passes on the profit to the Red states like Mississippi and Alaska, which have the largest per capita excess of Federal receipts over Federal taxes paid.

This is an outrage against seniors, who have no way to grow their savings and prepare for retirement. Social Security trust funds should be lent to homeowners and the income used to bolster the Social Security payments. This would virtually double social security payments.

To see this and other great ideas, go to YouTube and watch Comedy Party Platform (2 min 9 sec - yes, you do have time to watch it). The support me and Elizabeth Warren, the two people most likely to actually do something about it.

"From time to time I think of that stormy conference and wonder about the effect on our economy if, due to the actions of a few blocks of economically powerful and politically disgruntled states the US dollar ceases to be the reserve and international currency."

There are many advantages to the reserve currency status, but if you can suggest another currency to take its place, go ahead. I think you'll find it hard to find a reasonable replacement.

The thing that will stop the dollar from being the reserve currency won't be economic; it will be political.

I think there is a major question whether lowering interest rates below one or one and a half percent had any positive effect on the economy. For the most part it just  lowered the opportunity cost of holding money for the large banks and corporations. Not many loans were being made in any event. The principal beneficiaries were stock investors who have seen great returns in recent years, even as working people (and would-be working people) suffered from a devastated labor market. To say nothing of the suffering of people living on fixed incomes

Correct! But someone needs to convince the blue collar GOP supporters of this simple fact. To my knowledge, the Democrats have never made any concerted and serious attempt at showing the disningenuous policies of the Republicans that are leading too many lower, and lower-middle class workers to vote against their own economic interests.

Here's another reason for conservative inflation hawkery, that Krugman talked about back around Christmas time in his article "The Fear Economy":

Excessively low unemployment can tighten the labor market and increase workers' bargaining power to the point where income effectively redistributes from capital to labor. If your goal is to keep inequality high and labor weak, then full employment is the last thing you want to rally behind. Back in the late 1960s/early 1970s, many corporate leaders of the time were calling for a "disciplinary recession" to slacken the labor market and weaken upward wage pressures.
